In ontario, we have some freshwater mussels that use their mantle to mimic prey, like smaller fish, that then the fish can attack. Awesome video, I don’t recall them explaining why these species are so scarce now. However during the 19th and 20th centuries a large amount of it was them being collected for their shells which where used to make buttons with the mother of pearl look,  I do historical re-enactment and living history and have probably four dozen of them however they’re more responsible with them today, even being mad of substitutes. Still won’t reverse the fact it drove a species extinct in the upper Mississippi.

Oooh if only this video was out earlier DX it would have helped me out in a presentation I did some years back on the impact of dams on mussels some years ago: the dams prevent the fish carrying baby mussels from swimming upstream, so the mussel populations are isolated and have a smaller gene pool, leaving them susceptible to disease in the long run, even if they haven't already been wiped out during the construction of those dams!
